to make something else seem better or more attractive when combining with it: Strawberries and cream complement each other perfectly. The music complements her voice perfectly. Note: Do not confuse with compliment.

ComplementsComplements are one of the five major elements of clause structure. The other four are subject, verb, object and adjunct (complements are in bold): …
Subject and object complementsIn clauses with linking verbs (be, seem, become), complements which follow the verb and which add information about the subject are called subject complements: …
Complements and adjunctsComplements and adjuncts are different. A complement is necessary in order to complete the meaning. An adjunct is not necessary, and adds extra information. …

/ˌkɑm·pləˈmen·tə·ri, -tri/
This ancient Chinese therapy is part of the complementary treatment program for pain.
A complement is a number of people or things that makes something complete: We had a full complement of reporters and photographers along.
grammar A complement is part of a word or phrase that completes the predicate (= the part of a sentence that gives information about the subject), as “nothing” in “They told him nothing.”
